title: Are John Grisham’s books a series or is each book themed differently? Could I start at any book or do I need to read them in the order in which they were written? - Quora

response.answer_text: His novels are all standalone books, even though there are just a few characters that recur in three or four of them, the ones that deal with legal cases in a small town in Mississippi. No, you don’t need to read them in any order at all, even the ones with recurring characters, though if you do plow through them all, you might want to check plot summaries to see which ones are on that topic and read those few in order just because it might make sense to do that. I’ve never read his series for children, the Theodore Boone series. I think Theodore Boone is the name of the main character (a kid lawyer) in all of them, so maybe different rules apply.

Are John Grisham’s books a series or is each book themed differently? Could I start at any book or do I need to read them in the order in which they were written? The simple answer is, No—his books are not a series. A better answer would be to give you a link to Fantastic Fiction which is a superb site for researching any fiction authors. Not only are the authors listed, but their titles are listed as well. They are grouped in series, or individually, and by clicking on their title (or cover) we are able to read a summary of them. Take a look.

I assume he does not write books in series, they are standalone books. I had read only three books . The reckoning, the broker -they are fiction and the innocent man which is based on real life story. The reckoning is excellent, also enjoyed broker. but the last one is master piece. Presently I have with me “The Camino island, A time to kill and the firm and I will start reading “A time to kill” shortly
Most Grisham books are stand-alone; except for his Theodore Boone children’s series and the Whistler series, also for kids. Sycamore Row is the sequel to A Time to Kill, his first novel.
